turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: I am, there's too much flesh on me.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: Why does it matter whether you're fat or not...

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: ... You needn't worry about being attractive here.

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: I do, I have to be attractive to God.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: He loves you the way you are.

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: No he doesn't. He hates fat people.

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: It's a sin to be fat.

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: Look at the statues, they're thin.

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: That's because they're suffering... suffering is beautiful, I want to be beautiful.

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: Christ said it in the Bible, he said - suffer the little children, I want to suffer like a little child.

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: I... I am a little child but my body keeps getting bigger and soon I... I won't be able to fit in, I... I won't be able to squeeze into Heaven.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: Agnes dear, Heaven is not a place where...

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: No... I mean... I mean look at these. I've got to lose weight, I'm a blimp.

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: God blew up the Hindenburg. He'll blow me up, that's what she said...

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: Mommy I'll get bigger and bigger every day and then I'll pop but... but if I stay little it won't happen.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: Your mother tells you this?... Agnes your mother is dead.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: Nonsense, I'm your mother now and I want you to eat.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: You've got to eat something Agnes.

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: No I don't... the host is enough.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: My dear, I don't think a communion wafer has the recommended daily allowance of anything.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: Sister Marguerite says you have been sleeping on a bare mattress Sister. Is that true?

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: In the medieval days the nuns and monks would sleep in their own coffins.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: We're not in the Middle Ages, Sister.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: It made them uncomfortable. And if they didn't sleep well I'm certain the next day they were cranky as mules. Sister where are your sheets?  Do you really believe that sleeping on a bare mattress is the equivalent of sleeping in a coffin?

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: Then tell me. Where are your sheets?

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: How many times have I burned into your thick skull and the thick skull of your fellow novice, that menstruation is a perfectly natural process and nothing to be ashamed of.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: A few years ago one of the Sisters came to me in tears, asking for comfort, comfort because she was too old to have any children. Not that she wanted to, but once a month she had been reminded of that possibility.

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: It's not that... it's not that...

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: It's not my time of month.

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: I don't know. I don't know what happened Mother, I woke up... there was blood on the sheets, but I don't know what happened.  I don't know what I did wrong, I don't know and I should be punished.

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: I don't know... I don't know...

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: That was the beginning, the night of the conception. That's why she burnt the sheets.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Hello. I'm Doctor Livingston. I've been asked to talk to you. May I?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Hasn't anyone ever told you that before?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: What would you like to talk about.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: First thing that comes to your mind?

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: God!  But there's nothing to say about God.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Second thing that comes to your mind.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Agnes, have you ever loved another man... other than, Jesus Christ?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Well do you love... do you love Father Martineau?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Do you think he loves you?

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: No. But... when I look into his eyes, I can tell.

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: You want to talk about the baby don't you?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Would you like to talk about it?

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: I never saw any baby... I think they made it up.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Do you remember the night they said it came?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: In the middle of all the pain?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Where did the baby come from?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Is that where they say it came from... ?

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: No, they say it came from the waste paper basket!

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Where'd it come from before that?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: After God... before the waste-paper basket.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Yes I do,  but I want you to...

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: I don't understand what you're talking about... you want to talk about the baby... everybody wants to talk about the baby but... I never saw the baby so I can't talk about the baby because... I don't believe in the baby.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Then let's talk about something else...

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: No... no, I'm tired of talking, I've been talking for weeks, nobody believes me when I tell them anything... nobody listens to me.

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: No... no, I don't want to answer any more questions.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Would you like to ask them?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Just that... you ask and I'll answer.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: I can't have them any more.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Smoking is an obsession with me. Maybe one day I'll become obsessed with something else, then I'll stop smoking... Do you have any more questions?

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: Where do you think babies come from?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: From their mothers and fathers of course. Before that, I... I don't know.

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: Well I think they come from... angel lights on their mothers chest and whispers into her ear. That makes good babies start to grow. And bad babies come from when a fallen angel squeezes in down there, and they start to grow, grow, till they come out down there. I don't know where good babies come out. And you can't tell the difference... except bad babies cry a lot... and they make their fathers go away... and their mothers get very ill... die sometimes.

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: She was kind to me. She told me I was beautiful.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: What else did she tell you?

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: She said all of God's angels would want to sleep beside me if they could. I liked that.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Sister Paul was in her eighties?  Did she climb up here often?

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: No, only when she felt like it. She brought me up here last winter and the next day she died.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: No wonder... wait... Agnes... Agnes how do you feel about babies?

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: Oh, they frighten me, I'm afraid I'll drop them. They have a soft spot on their heads and if you drop them so they land on their heads they become stupid. I was dropped on my head, that's why I don't understand things.

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: Numbers... you can spend your whole life counting and never reach the end.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: I don't understand them either. Do you suppose I was dropped on my head?

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: I hope not. It's a terrible thing to be dropped on your head.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Oh, I've got to give up smoking. Agnes ... wait a minute... Agnes slow down.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: What happens if the bell rings and you're under there?

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: Oh, it's even more wonderful then.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: It's like hiding from my mother when I was a little girl.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Oh, no place as wonderful as this. Agnes... have you ever thought of leaving the convent for something else?

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: No. There is nothing else. Just being here at night helps me sleep.

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: I get headaches. Mommy did too... oh, but she wasn't stupid. She knew things that nobody else knew.

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: She knew what was going to happen to me. That's why she hid me away.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: I promise I won't laugh. Who told her?

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: An angel, when she was having one of her headaches.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Did your mother see angels often?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Do you believe she really saw them?

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: No, but I can never tell her that.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Agnes, did you love your mother?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Did you ever want to be a mother yourself?

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: I could never be a mother.

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: Well I don't think I'm old enough and besides I don't want to have a baby.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: If you did want one, how'd you go about getting one?

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: From someone who didn't want to have a baby.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: How would that person get one if they didn't want one?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Agnes, how did your mother get you?

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: A mistake... it was a mistake...

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: If you're trying to get me to say that she was a bad woman and hated me and didn't want me but that's not true, she was a good woman, a saint...

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Agnes, I don't believe you know nothing about sex...

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: I can't help it if I'm stupid.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: ... that you don't remember getting pregnant...

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: ... and that you don't believe you carried a child.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Agnes, I'm here because I want to help you.

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: That's because you keep reminding me. If you go away then I'll forget.

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: Everyone's unhappy, you're unhappy aren't you?

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: Answer me!  You never answer me.

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: Only you think you're lucky because you didn't have a mother who said things to you and did things to you that maybe weren't always nice but that was because of me, because I was bad, not her.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Agnes. What did your mother do to you?  If you can't answer me, just shake your head yes or no. Did... did she hit you?  Did she make you do something you didn't want to?  Did it make you feel uncomfortable to do it?  Did it embarrass you?  Did it... did it hurt you?  What did she make you you do?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: She can't hurt you any more.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Agnes, I don't believe that. Tell me. I'll protect you from her.

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: ... take off my clothes and then... she makes fun of me.

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: She says my whole body's a mistake.

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: Because she says if I don't watch out I'll have a baby.

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: She touches me down there with a cigarette.  Please Mommy, don't touch me like that any more. I'll be good,  I won't be a baby any more.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Agnes, oh Agnes, Agnes I want you to do something. I want you to pretend that I'm your mother. Oh yes, only this time I want you to tell me what you're feeling, alright?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Please!  I want to help you. Let me help you.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Agnes, you're ugly!... what do you say? Of course you do. Agnes, you're ugly!... what do you say?

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: I'm not mistake, I'm here aren't I. How can I be a mistake if I'm really here. God doesn't make mistakes, you're a mistake...

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Oh Agnes, oh Agnes, it's alright, it's alright, it's alright, it's alright, I love you.

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: Do you really love me or are you just saying that?

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: As much as Mother Miriam does?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: As much as God loves you.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: You're listening to a chorus of angels. The music surrounds you like a... warm and, comfortable pool of water. And while you're sleeping, you're going to be able to recall, all the things that we want you to remember. And when I count to three and clap my hands, you'll no longer be hypnotised. Can you hear me.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Good. Would you like to tell me why you're here?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: What kind of trouble?  What kind of trouble Agnes?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: But it's easy. It's just a breath with sound. Say it. What kind of trouble?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: How did you have a baby?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Did you know what was going to come out?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Did you want it to come out?

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: May I open my eyes now?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: No not yet Agnes, very soon but not yet. How did the baby get into you?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: What made it grow?  Do you know?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Would you like to tell me?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Did anyone else know about the baby?

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: She made me promise not to.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Who?  Who made you promise?  It's alright Agnes. It's alright.  Let's go to your room. It's the night about six weeks ago when you were very sick.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Oh don't be, I'm here. It's alright. I want you to tell me what you did before you went to bed.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Hm hmm. What did you have for dinner?

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: We went to chapel for vespers.

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: I left early because I wasn't feeling very well.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Was it Sister Marguerite who knew about the baby?  Alright Agnes, I want you to see your room as you saw it on that night.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Above the bed?  Any... anything else? What do you you see, something different?  What is it?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Do you know who put it there?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: What do you think it's there for?

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: For me to get sick in.

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: I feel as if I've eaten glass.

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: Of me. Oh... God!  My God...  Water... it's all water...

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: They can't hear me that's why.  Oh God... I don't wanna...

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: Go away, I don't want you here.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Is someone in the room with you?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Alright Agnes... it's alright. One, two three...  It's alright... it's me, Doctor Livingston, it's alright, alright. Thankyou Agnes, thankyou. How do you feel?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Do you remember what just happened?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: That's good. Do you feel well enough to stand?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: I want you to remember if you can a night last January. The night Sister Paul died. Do you remember.

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: The statue. She had shown it to me the day before.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: And the passage to the barn?

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: So I could go to him.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: How did she know about him?

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: From the belltower the day she before she died.

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: It's bleeding... I'm bleeding... my God it won't stop, I can't get it to stop.  Let go of me, I wish you were dead.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Agnes it had nothing to do with the hand of God. He did a terrible thing to you, do you understand?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: He frightened you and he hurt you. It's not your fault. It's his fault. Tell us who he is so we can find him. Stop him from doing this to other women.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Of course you do. Who was it?

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: I hate him for what he did to me.

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: For what he made me go through.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Agnes, who did this to you?

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: God!  It was God.  And now I'll burn in hell because I hate him.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Agnes you won't burn in hell. It's alright to hate him.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Mother Miriam was with you wasn't she?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: She took the baby in her arms?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: You saw it all didn't you?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: And then... what did she do?  Agnes what did she do?

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: She... left me alone with that little thing, and I looked at it, and I thought this is a mistake. But it's my mistake, not Mommy's. God's mistake.

turns.speaker: AGNES
turns.text: I tied the cord around her neck... wrapped her in the bloody sheets... and stuffed her in the trash can.

turns.speaker: ELDERLY NUN
turns.text: I've been watching. We were fine 'till she came. She brought the devil here.  There was blood on her hand that night.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Are you dictating my position to me? We're getting into some sticky legal territories here.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Martha, all we're saying is, no-one wants this to come to trial, not the Church, not the Crown... least of all me.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Nobody is interested in sending a nun to prison.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Martha, you have to make a decision on her sanity as quickly as possible and not interfere with due process of law.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: No... no, excuse me Eve. As quickly as I see fit.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: The longer you take to make a decision, the more difficult it will be for us.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: The bishop is breathing down our necks.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: And the sooner she goes to prison, the better off she'll be?

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: Here you are. Don't let anyone know where you got them.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: Marty, what are you doing here?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Larry there's got to be something missing.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: I gave you the pictures Marty, what else do you want?

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: What?  You think that the girl is innocent?

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: What's the matter with you, you've seen the reports. It's a cut and dried case.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Maybe there's something that's not in the report that should be.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: You're too involved Marty.  Jesus look at you. Why don't you turn this case over to someone else?

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: If I find anything I'll call you.

turns.speaker: LEVEAU
turns.text: Would you tell me why the hell this is taking so long.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Look there are a lot of unanswered questions here.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: I don't believe this. I don't bloody believe this.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: All I want is one more week.

turns.speaker: LEVEAU
turns.text: Why?  You've done nothing to show any progress.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Yes, that's because I'm getting to her.

turns.speaker: LEVEAU
turns.text: You're getting to all of us Martha, let's face it.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: I'll have a decision by next week.

turns.speaker: LEVEAU
turns.text: It's gone on long enough. You're out.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Oh Joe... Joe she didn't kill the baby.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: I can get you new evidence next week.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Tomorrow... tomorrow, I'll get it by tomorrow. I will.

turns.speaker: MAMA
turns.text: Shut up, I'm trying to watch this.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: It's Martha, Mama.  There you go.

turns.speaker: MAMA
turns.text: Marie brings me icecream too you know. Chocolate... my favourite.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: I thought cherry-vanilla was your favourite.

turns.speaker: MAMA
turns.text: Not any more... now I like chocolate.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Did you have a good week Mama. Are they treating you all right?

turns.speaker: MAMA
turns.text: You know Martha never comes to see me. You watch it, she's going straight to hell... after all the things she said to me. Then she marries that son of a bitch of a Frenchman... has an abortion. I knew that one wouldn't work out. Not like you Marie. You got married to God.

turns.speaker: MAMA
turns.text: I remember when you was a little girl Marie. You come back from the movies and you'd say - Mama that ending was so sad... and I'd tell you they had all the happy endings locked away in a vault in Hollywood.  And you believed me.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Mama, that wasn't Marie, that was me!

turns.speaker: SISTER ANNE
turns.text: The convent was built for over fifty. Not many of us left... just us and the chickens.

turns.speaker: SISTER ANNE
turns.text: Oh, we own the land around here. But we rent it out. We keep a few acres for ourselves,  some wheat, corn, some vegetables.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Well that's a lot of land. You must have help. Do you have field hands that help you?

turns.speaker: SISTER ANNE
turns.text: No. We work the land alone. No-one but Sister Marguerite and I are permitted contact with the public.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Sister Anne, which was Agnes' room?

turns.speaker: SISTER ANNE
turns.text: Oh that one there, in the corner.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: The one up on the third floor?

turns.speaker: MONSIGNOR
turns.text: Well you're probably right about that. It certainly can't help Sister Agnes to have this investigation continued for any length of time.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Why do you call it an investigation? I never have.

turns.speaker: MONSIGNOR
turns.text: Your mother was a resident of Saint Catherines home before you moved her.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: What does this have to do with..?

turns.speaker: MONSIGNOR
turns.text: And you had a sister who died in the convent.

turns.speaker: MONSIGNOR
turns.text: Do you still go to church?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: What business is it of yours..?

turns.speaker: MONSIGNOR
turns.text: Oh, we just wonder if you can be very objective about this case.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Look, Father, ah... just because I don't subscribe to the... to the beliefs you subscribe to...

turns.speaker: MONSIGNOR
turns.text: But what you believe makes no difference to us whatsoever Doctor. But it does make all the difference to Agnes.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: I don't understand. Are you expecting me to..?

turns.speaker: MONSIGNOR
turns.text: Well somone's got to suffer for this Doctor. You've got to be merciful and quick. Excuse me.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: I'm afraid the word brings up the most unpleasant connatations in this day and age...

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: You must have tons of questions. You may smoke if you want to. Just don't tell any of the Sisters.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: How did she hide it from the other nuns?

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: She undressed alone... she bathed alone.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: How did she hide it during the day?

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: She could have hidden a machine gun in here if she had wanted to.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Didn't she have any physical examinations in this time?

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: We're examined once a year. Her pregnancy fell in between the doctor's visits.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: What man had access to her?

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: None as far as I know.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: Father Martineau, but I don't see him as a candidate.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Could there have been anyone else?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: And you didn't try to find out who?

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: Believe me, I've done everything possible short of asking Agnes.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: She can't even remember the birth. Do you think she'd admit to the conception?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Look, someone gave her the baby.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: Yes, but that was some ten months ago. I fail to see that the identity of that somebody has anything to do with this trial.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: Don't ask me those questions dear, I'm not the patient.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Well I'm the doctor. I'm the one who's going to decide what is, or is not important here.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: Look doctor, I don't know how to tell you this politely, but I don't approve of you. Not you personally...

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: Exactly. I want you do deal with Agnes as speedily and as easily as possible. She won't hold up under any sort of cross examination.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: I am not with the Inquisition.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: And I am not from the Middle Ages. I know what you are!  I don't want that mind cut open.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: Well... what do you think?  Is she totally bananas or merely slightly off centre... or maybe she's perfectly sane and just a very good liar.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: From other nuns...  Yes I... I've noticed.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: From other people!  I believe she is not crazy, nor is she lying.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: How could she have a baby and know nothing of sex or birth?

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: Because she's an innocent. She's a slate that's hasn't been touched except by God.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: In her case it isn't. She's had very little schooling. Her mother kept her home almost all the time and when her mother died Agnes came here, to us. She's never been out there Doctor. She's never seen a movie or a television show. She's never even read a book.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: If she's so innocent, how come she murdered a child?

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: She didn't!  This is manslaughter, not murder. She didn't consciously kill that baby. She'd lost a lot of blood. She was unconscious by the time we got to her.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: So, someone else could have done it.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: No... not in the eyes of the police.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: I've already told you what I thought.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: That she was unconscious, yes!  So someone easily could have come in the room and killed the...

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: You don't really believe something like that happened do you?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: One of the other nuns found out about the baby and... and wanted to avoid a scandal.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: That possibility never occurred to you?

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: No-one knew about Agnes' pregnancy. No-one. Not even Agnes.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: This convent is locked solid. The only one that has a key is Sister Marguerite and she wouldn't let Christ in after dark.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Well, it's been known to happen in the day too. Maybe Agnes went to him.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: Oh come on, you've talked to her. She doesn't even know how babies are born, let alone made.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: When did you first learn about her... innocence, the way she thinks?

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: Shortly after she came to us.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: I was appalled, just as you are now.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Why didn't you take her to a doctor?

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: It was healed by the following morning and she started eating again...

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: She had a... a hole in the palm of her hand!  She could have bled to death.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: But she didn't... did she. If anyone had seen what I'd seen she'd be public property... newspapermen, psychiatrists, ridicule. She doesn't deserve that.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: I know what you're thinking, she's a hysteric pure and simple.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: I saw it. Clean through the palm of her hand. Do you think hysteria could do that?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: It's being doing it for centuries. She's not unique, she's just another victim.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: God's victim. That's her innocence. She belongs to God.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: And I intend to take her away from Him. That's what you're afraid of isn't it?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: I haven't said anything against the the Catholic Church.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: Catholicism is not on trial here. I want you to deal with Agnes without any religious prejudice or you turn this case over to someone else...

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: How dare you tell me to run my affairs!

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: How dare you think I'm in a position to be pressured...

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: ... or bullied or what ever you're doing. Who the hell do you think you are?  You go around here expecting applause for the way you treated this child.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: And she has a right to know that there's a world out there filled with people who don't believe in God...  ... and aren't any worse off than you Mother. People who've gone through their entire lives without bending their knees once, to anybody. And people who fall in love and have babies and occas- sionally are very happy. She has a right to know that. But you and your... your order and your Church have kept her ignorant...

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: ???   ... virginity, right Mother?  Poverty, chastity and ignorance is what you live by.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: I am not a virgin, Doctor. I was married for twenty three years, two daughters. I even have grandchildren... surprised? It might please you to know that I was a failure as a wife and mother. My children won't even see me any more, that's their revenge. I think they tell their friends that I've passed on. And don't tell me I'm making up for past mistakes Doctor Freud.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: No, you're shielding her. Let her face the world.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: What good would it do. No matter what you decide it's either the... the prison or the nut house and the differences between them are pretty thin.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Innocence. Legal innocence. I know the judge would be happy for any reason to throw this case out of court.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: All right, what do you need.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: When would Agnes have conceived the child?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Do you remember anything unusual happening at the time?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Do you have a... a diary or a day book?

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: Oh, Dear God, I should have guessed...

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: The twenty third of January. On that night one of our elder nuns passed away.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: Yes. I don't remember where Agnes was. I was needed in the sick room.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: I didn't tell you because I didn't think it was important.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: No, it just makes you doubly responsible doesn't it?

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: I never saw Agnes until she set foot in this convent. My sister ran away from home. We lost touch with her. And when my husband died and I came here, she wrote to me and asked me if I would take care of Agnes in case anything happened.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Like keeping her home from school?

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: She drank too much. That's what killed her.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Do you know what she did to her?

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: I don't think I care to know.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: There is more here than meets the eye isn't there?  Lots of dirty little secrets.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: Oh God, if only I'd known.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Why didn't you?  You knew she was keeping her home from school. You knew she was an alcoholic.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: I knew that after the fact.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Why didn't you do anything to stop her?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: The woman's health is at stake.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: I don't give a damn about her spiritual health.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: She's happy with us and she could go on being happy if she was left alone.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Then why did you call the police in the first place Mother, huh?

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: Because I am a moral person.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Catholic Church doesn't have a corner on morality...

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: Who said anything about the Catholic Church...

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: What the hell has the Catholic Church got to do with you?

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: What have we done to hurt you?  And don't deny it, I can smell an ex-Catholic a mile away. What did we do?  Burn a few heretics, sell some indulgences? That was in the days when the Church was a ruling body. We let governments do those things today. So what did we do to you eh?  You wanted to neck in the back seat of a car when you were fifteen and you couldn't because it was a sin?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: It wasn't sex. It was a lot of things, but it wasn't sex. You know when I was in the first grade my best friend was run over on the way to school, you know what the nun said?  She died because she hadn't said her morning prayers.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: That's all?  That's enough!  She was a beautiful little girl.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: And what has that to do with it?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: I wasn't. I wasn't. She was the pretty one. She died, why not me?  I never said my morning prayers. And I was ugly, I was scrawny, I had buck teeth and freckles all over my face, do you know what the nun called me, Sister Mary Clitus, called me Polkadot Livingston.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: So you left the Church because you had freckles?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: No, because I... yeah, yeah I left the Church cause I had freckles.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: My sister died in a convent. And it's her voice I hear.  Does my smoking bother you?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Do you suppose the saints would have smoked if tobacco had been popular back then?

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: Undoubtedly. Not the ascetics of course but, well Saint Thomas More...

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: Saint Ignatius would smoke cigars and stub them out on the soles of his bare feet.  And of course

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Oh, you've come a long way baby.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: And Saint John would chew tobacco.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Right.  What do you suppose today's saints are smoking?

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: There are no saints today. Good people yes, but extraordinarily good people... those I'm afraid we are sorely lacking.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Do you think they ever existed?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Do you want to become one?

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: Become?  One is born a saint.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Well you can try, can't you, to be good?

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: Yes, but goodness has very little to do with it. Not all the saints were good, in fact some of them were a little crazy. But... they were still attached to God. Agnes has that birth.  No more... we're born, we live, we die. No room for miracles.  Oh my dear, how I miss the miracles.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Do you think Agnes is still attached to God?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: The hypnotism. Do you still disapprove?

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: Would it stop you if I did?

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: Stop this, she'll hurt herself  I'm not going to allow this.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: NO... no... I said leave her alone.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: I've just met with the bishop. We're taking you off the case.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: If we want to hire a psychiatrist for Agnes. we'll find our own, thank you.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: One that will ask the questions you want asked.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: One that will approach this matter with some objectivity and respect.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: She's been touched by God, yes.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: How?  How?  She hallucinates, stops eating and bleeds spontaneously. Is that supposed to convince me she shouldn't be touched. Give me a miracle.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: My God, you're as crazy as...

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: Stop laughing, I don't say it's the truth, I'm saying...

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Well give me a reasonable explanation

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: A miracle is an event without an explanation. If she's capable of putting a hole in her hand without benefit of a nail, why couldn't she split a cell in her womb?

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: There as no man in the convent on that night and no way for any man to get in or out.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: You'll never find the answer for everything God did.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: I thought you didn't believe in miracles today Mother?

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: But I want the opportunity to believe. I want the choice to believe.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: But what you are choosing to believe is a lie because you won't face the fact that she was raped... or seduced... or that she did the seducing.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: But she is not an enigma Mother. Everything that Agnes has done is explainable from modern psychiatry. One, two, three, right down the line.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: That's what you believe she is?  The sum of her psychological parts?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: That's what I have to believe...

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: Then why are you so obsessed with her? You're losing sleep over her?  You're thinking about her all the time. You're bent on saving her. Why?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: There's a tunnel out of the crypt into the barn. Did you know about that? There's an answer Mother. That's how she got out.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: That's crazy. How could she find out about it?

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: Who?  That tun... that tunnel hasn't been used in fifty years.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Oh, would you stop lying Mother!

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Because it's murder we're talking about. Aren't you concerned about what she told us about the other person in her room.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Who was that person Mother?  Was it you?

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: If you believe this is murder, it is the Crown attorney you have to talk to, not me. And definitely not Agnes.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: This is permission to take her apart.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: I have a few more questions to ask her.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: Why do you insist upon pressing...

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: Is it because she's a nun?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Did you know she was pregnant?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: And you didn't send her to a doctor.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: I didn't guess until it was too late.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: I don't know... too late to stop it.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: You went to the room to help with the birth.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: You wanted that child out of the way.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: You hid the wastepaper basket in her room.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: I didn't hide it. I put it there for the blood and the dirty sheets.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: You tied the cord around its neck.

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: I wanted her to have it when no-one else was around, they would have taken the baby to a hospital and left it with them, but it was such a difficult birth, there was so much blood and I panicked.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Before or after you killed the child?

turns.speaker: MOTHER MIRIAM
turns.text: I left it with her and I went for help.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: I doubt that's what she'd say.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Agnes, what happened to the baby?

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: Yes, they were playing the queues outside the picture palaces of Liverpool. Scruffy young lads, lacking even the price of a jam roll. Orphans, every Paddy's son of 'em. I saw their potential at once although I had me doubts about the little fella, a savage primitive, that Ringo, but it was him what gave in first. He picked up a brick and heaved it at me and I quelled him wid one fierce flash of me eyes. "Mister, can you spare us a copper?" he said. I was disarmed by the grubby little outstretched mauler ... So, I took them under me managerial banner.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: Oh, not at all, I let them have twenty-five; sure aren't there four of them?

turns.speaker: AUDREY
turns.text: How fascinating. Do go on ...  ... John.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: ... Oh, I'm all heart, Ma'am, all heart ... Well, I let ...

turns.speaker: BLONDE
turns.text: Your cards... lay them down... face up.
